  • CDS: Concurrent Data Structures library
  • Terms and concepts

Type rebinding

Frequently, the container stores user-provided values in internal item structure with other data that is private for the container. At the moment of container declaration this internal container's type is unspecified and often is unaccessible (private) for the user code, only type of value storing in the container is knew. To solve this problem a trick called rebinding is widely used. For example, 

    template <typename T>
    class a_cont {
    public:
        template <typename T2>
        struct rebind {
            typedef a_cont<T2> other ;    // Rebinding result
        };
    };

This example demonstrates how the container of type a_cont that stores the values of user-level type T may be rebind to other container of type a_cont for storing values of other type T2.

Many containers in libcds relies on existence of rebind feature for their template arguments and implicitly use rebinding.
